comments.content:
It looks like a custom typeface by Mucca Design for Brooklyn Fare.  
 [http://www.mucca.com/work/brooklyn-fare-3](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414042918/http:/www.mucca.com/work/brooklyn-fare-3 "http://www.mucca.com/work/brooklyn-fare-3")  
 [http://www.mucca.com/case-studies/brooklyn-fare](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414042918/http:/www.mucca.com/case-studies/brooklyn-fare "http://www.mucca.com/case-studies/brooklyn-fare")  
 [http://www.eatmedaily.com/2009/07/brooklyn-fares-packaging-and-graphic-d...](http://web.archive.org/web/20150414042918/http:/www.eatmedaily.com/2009/07/brooklyn-fares-packaging-and-graphic-design/ "http://www.eatmedaily.com/2009/07/brooklyn-fares-packaging-and-graphic-design/")

A very effective 21st century reinterpretation of Clarendon.  
Brooklyn Fare packaging is plastered with "Fare Serif" -- Mucca's bespoke font -- but the Brooklyn Fare website uses Clarendon as a substitute.  
Don
